{{Redirect|Smartphones|the song by Trey Songz|SmartPhones (song)}} [[File:Iphone-5s-black.png|thumb|The front and back of an [[iPhone 5S]] smartphone, launched in 2013]] A '''smartphone''' (or '''smart phone''') is a [[mobile phone]] with more advanced computing capability and connectivity than basic [[feature phone]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.phonescoop.com/glossary/term.php?gid=131 |title=Smartphone |publisher=''Phone Scoop'' |accessdate=2011-12-15}}{{cite web |url=http://www.phonescoop.com/glossary/term.php?gid=310 |title=Feature Phone |publisher=''Phone Scoop'' |accessdate=2011-12-15}}{{cite web |url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/gadgetreviews/smartphone-vs-feature-phone-arms-race-heats-up-which-did-you-buy/6836 |title=Smartphone vs. feature phone arms race heats up; which did you buy? |author=Andrew Nusca |date=20 August 2009 |publisher=[[ZDNet]] |accessdate=2011-12-15}}Smartphones typically include the features of a computer with those of another popular consumer device, such as a [[personal digital assistant]], a [[portable media player|media player]], a [[digital camera]], and/or a [[GPS Phone|GPS navigation unit]]. Later smartphones include all of those plus the features of a [[touchscreen]] computer, including [[Web browser|web browsing]], [[Wi-Fi]], 3rd-party [[mobile app|apps]], [[motion sensor]] and [[mobile payment]].
Currently, about 84% of handset sales worldwide are for devices driven by [[Google|Google's]] [[Android (operating system)|Android]] with [[Apple Inc.|Apple's]] [[iOS]] [[mobile operating systems]] a distant second at around 12%.{{cite news|title=Nokia revenues slide 24% but Lumia sales rise offers hope|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2013/jul/18/nokia-revenues-fall-lumia-sales?CMP=EMCNEWEML6619I2|accessdate=19 July 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 July 2013|author=Charles Arthur}}{{cite web|title= Worldwide Smartphone Shipments Edge Past 300 Million Units in the Second Quarter; Android and iOS Devices Account for 96% of the Global Market, According to IDC |url=http://www.idc.com/getdoc.jsp?containerId=prUS25037214 |accessdate=4 September 2014|publisher=IDC |date=14 August 2014}}
==History==
===Early years===
Devices that combined telephony and computing were first conceptualized by Theodore G. Paraskevakos in 1971 and patented in 1973, and were offered for sale beginning in 1993. He was the first to introduce the concepts of intelligence, data processing and visual display screens into telephones which gave rise to the "Smartphone." In 1971, Paraskevakos, working with [[Boeing]] in [[Huntsville, Alabama]], demonstrated a transmitter and receiver that provided additional ways to communicate with remote equipment, however it did not yet have general purpose [[PDA]] applications in a wireless device typical of smartphones. They were installed at Peoples' Telephone Company in Leesburg, Alabama and were demonstrated to several telephone companies. The original and historic working models are still in the possession of Paraskevakos.{{cn|date=September 2014}}
===Forerunners===
[[File:IBM Simon Personal Communicator.png|thumb|150px|upright|[[IBM Simon]] and charging base (1993{{cite web|title=Watch The Incredible 70-Year Evolution Of The Cell Phone|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/complete-visual-history-of-cell-phones-2011-5/1938-1#1993-13|work=Business Insider|publisher=Business Insider, Inc|accessdate=8 January 2014}})]]
The first mobile phone to incorporate [[PDA]] features was an [[IBM]] prototype developed in 1992 and demonstrated that year at the [[COMDEX]] computer industry trade show. A refined version of the product was marketed to consumers in 1994 by [[BellSouth]] under the name [[IBM Simon|Simon Personal Communicator]]. The Simon was the first device that can be properly referred to as a "smartphone", even though that term was not yet coined.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-06-29/before-iphone-and-android-came-simon-the-first-smartphone |title=Before IPhone and Android Came Simon, the First Smartphone |last=Sager |first=Ira |date=2012-06-29 |publisher=Bloomberg L.P |work=Bloomberg Businessweek |accessdate=2012-06-30 |quote=Simon was the first smartphone. Twenty years ago, it envisioned our app-happy mobile lives, squeezing the features of a cell phone, pager, fax machine, and computer into an 18-ounce black brick.}}{{cite news |last=Schneidawind |first=John |title=Poindexter putting finger on PC bugs; Big Blue unveiling |date=1992-11-23 |newspaper=USA Today |page=2B}}{{cite web|last1=Connelly|first1=Charlotte|title=World's first 'smartphone' celebrates 20 years|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-28802053|website=BBC News|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=16 August 2014}} In addition to its ability to make and receive cellular phone calls, Simon was also able to send and receive [[faxes]] and e-mails and included several other apps like address book, calendar, appointment scheduler, calculator, world time clock, and note pad through its touch screen display. Simon is the first smartphone to be incorporated with the features of a PDA[http://www.spinfold.com/first-touchscreen-phone/ History of first touchscreen smartphone] Spinfold.com
The term "smart phone" appeared in print in 1995, for describing AT&T's "PhoneWriter(TM) Communicator" as a "smart phone".{{cite web |url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=208157 |title=Designing a GUI for Business Telephone users|last=Savage |first=Pamela |date=January 1995 |publisher=Association of Computing Machinery |accessdate=2014-09-13 |quote=...It is at this point that early usability test participants met impasse. The switch connected to our "smart phone" is expecting the typical "dumb end-point"... AT&T's PhoneWriter was demonstrated at the 1993 Comdex Computer Show...}}
===PDAs===
In the late 1990s, many mobile phone users carried a separate dedicated [[PDA]] device, running early versions of operating systems such as [[Palm OS]], [[BlackBerry OS]] or [[Windows CE]]/[[Pocket PC]]. These operating systems would later evolve into [[mobile operating system]]s.
In 1996, [[Nokia]] released the [[Nokia 9000]] which combined a [[personal digital assistant|PDA]] based on the [[GEOS V3.0]] operating system from [[Geoworks]] with a digital cellular phone based on the [[Nokia 2110]]. The two devices were fixed together via a hinge in what became known as a [[clamshell design]]. When opened, the display was on the inside top surface and with a physical [[QWERTY keyboard]] on the bottom. The personal organizer provided e-mail, calendar, address book, calculator and notebook with text-based web browsing, and the ability to send and receive faxes. When the personal organizer was closed, it could be used as a digital cellular phone.
In June 1999, [[Qualcomm]] released a "CDMA Digital PCS Smartphone" with integrated Palm PDA and Internet connectivity, known as the "pdQ Smartphone".{{cite web | url=http://www.qualcomm.com/media/releases/1999/06/15/qualcomm-s-pdq-smartphone-provides-ideal-platform-wireless-business | title=Qualcomm s pdQ Smartphone | publisher=''qualcomm.com''}}
In early 2000, the [[Ericsson R380]] was released by [[Ericsson Mobile Communications]],{{cite web | url=http://www.geek.com/hwswrev/pda/ericr380/ | title=PDA Review: Ericsson R380 Smartphone | publisher=''Geek.com'' | accessdate=27 April 2011}} and was the first device marketed as a "smartphone".{{cite web | url=http://www.mobilemag.com/2001/09/25/ericsson-introduces-the-new-r380e | title=Ericsson Introduces The New R380e | publisher=''Mobile Magazine'' | accessdate=27 April 2011}} It combined the functions of a mobile phone and a [[personal digital assistant]] (PDA), supported limited web browsing with a resistive touchscreen utilizing a stylus.{{cite news | url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,40827,00.asp | title=Ericsson R380 World Review & Rating | publisher=''PCMag.com'' | accessdate=27 April 2011}}
In early 2001, [[Palm, Inc.]] introduced the [[Kyocera 6035]], which combined a PDA with a mobile phone and operated on [[Verizon Wireless|Verizon]]. It also supported limited web browsing.{{cite web |url=http://www.palminfocenter.com/view_story.asp?ID=1707 |title=Kyocera QCP 6035 Smartphone Review |publisher=Palminfocenter.com |date=2001-03-16 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}{{cite news |last=Segan |first=Sascha |url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2361664,00.asp |title=Kyocera Launches First Smartphone In Years | News & Opinion |publisher=PCmag.com |date=2010-03-23 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}
Smartphones before Android, iOS, and Blackberry, typically ran on [[Symbian]], which was originally developed by [[Psion]]. It was the world's most widely used smartphone operating system until Q4 2010.
===Mass adoption===
In 1999, the Japanese firm [[NTT Docomo]] released the first smartphones to achieve mass adoption within a country. These phones ran on [[i-mode]], which provided data transmission speeds up to 9.6 kbit/s.{{cite journal|last=Rose|first=Frank|title=Pocket Monster: How DoCoMo's wireless Internet service went from fad to phenom - and turned Japan into the first post-PC nation|journal=Wired|date=Sep 2001|volume=9|issue=9|url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/9.09/docomo_pr.html|accessdate=24 January 2014}} Unlike future generations of wireless services, [[NTT Docomo]]'s [[i-mode]] used [[cHTML]], a language which restricted some aspects of traditional [[HTML]] in favor of increasing data speed for the devices. Limited functionality, small screens and limited bandwidth allowed for phones to maximize the slower data speeds available.{{cite book|last=Barnes, Stuart J|first=Huff, Sid L.|title=Rising Sun: iMode and the Wireless Internet|date=November 2003/Vol. 46, No. 1|publisher=Communications of the ACM|pages=79–84}}
The rise of [[i-mode]] helped [[NTT Docomo]] accumulate an estimated 40 million subscribers by the end of 2001. It was also ranked first in market capitalization in Japan and second globally. This power would wane in the face of the rise of 3G and new phones with advanced wireless network capabilities.{{cite web|last=Anwar|first=Sayid Tariq|title=NTT DoCoMo and M-Commerce: A Case Study in Market Expansion and Global Strategy|url=http://www.itu.dk/~rold/1_sem/B1/Cases/DoCoMo.pdf|publisher=The American Graduate School of International Management|accessdate=16 February 2014}}
Outside of Japan smartphones were still a rare feature, although throughout the mid-2000s, devices based on Microsoft's [[Windows Mobile]] started to gain high popularity among businessmen and businesswomen in the U.S. The [[BlackBerry]] later gained mass adoption in the U.S., which in 2006 popularized the term CrackBerry due to its addictive nature.{{cite news|title=Info Addicts Are All Thumbs: Crackberry Is the 2006 Word of the Year|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/websters-new-worldr-college-dictionary-info-addicts-are-all-thumbs-55824847.html|accessdate=24 January 2014|newspaper=PR Newswire|date=Nov 1, 2006}} The company first released its GSM BlackBerry 6210, BlackBerry 6220, & BlackBerry 6230 devices in 2003. Also released was the Blackberry 7730 which featured a color screen.{{cite web|last=Halevy|first=Ron|title=The History of RIM & the BlackBerry Smartphone, Part 3: The Evolution Of Color|url=http://www.berryreview.com/2009/03/16/the-history-of-rim-the-blackberry-smartphone-part-3-the-evolution-of-color/|accessdate=16 February 2014}} In 2006 and 2007, both operating systems were in a large lead in the North American market, although while BlackBerry was popular among both business people and young people, Windows Mobile was only popular in the former.
These successive waves of phone technology allowed users to email, fax and make traditional calls, making it a useful tool for business travelers. As the Blackberry gained customers, less sophisticated users were attracted to its many communication options.
In Europe, Windows Mobile was never a large player in the market, and BlackBerry didn't make a notable impact in the market until around 2008. Symbian was the most popular smartphone OS in Europe during the mid and late 2000s. This was largely led by Nokia, which has always been a popular brand outside of North America. Initially Nokia's Symbian devices were focused on business, the same way as Windows Mobile and BlackBerry devices at the time. From 2006 onwards, Nokia started to make entertainment-focused smartphones, which were popularized by the Nseries. The N95, for instance, had breakthrough multimedia features for its time, and marked the start of a broader market of smartphones within younger people, and not just business. In Asia (except Japan), the trend was similar to Europe's.
Another company that made a breakthrough was the Palm. Although originally PDAs, Palms later turned into business-focused smartphones, largely competing with BlackBerry and Windows Mobile in the U.S. market, and was less popular in Europe and Asia.
All leaders of the 2000s suffered following the release of the iPhone.
===iPhone & Android===
In 2007, [[Apple Inc.]] introduced the [[iPhone (original)|iPhone]], one of the first mobile phones to use a [[multi-touch]] interface. The iPhone was notable for its use of a large touchscreen for direct finger input as its main means of interaction, instead of a [[Stylus (computing)|stylus]], keyboard, or keypad typical for smartphones at the time.{{cite web |url=http://www.engadget.com/2007/01/09/the-iphone-is-not-a-smartphone/ |title=The iPhone is not a smartphone |date=9 January 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2010|publisher=Engadget.com}} 2008 saw the release of the first phone to use [[Android (operating system)|Android]] called the [[HTC Dream]] (also known as the T-Mobile G1). Android is an [[open source|open-source]] platform founded by Andy Rubin and backed by [[Google]].{{cite web |url= http://www.openhandsetalliance.com/oha_members.html |title=Alliance Members |work=Open Handset Alliance |accessdate=16 January 2011 }}[http://www.cnet.com/android-atlas/ The Android Atlas] Cnet.com. Retrieved 21 August 2013. Although Android's adoption was relatively slow at first, it started to gain widespread popularity in 2010, and now dominates the market.
Both of these platforms led to the drop of the previous leading companies. Microsoft, for instance, started a new OS from scratch, in the form of [[Windows Phone]], which is now the third largest OS. Nokia abandoned Symbian and partnered with Microsoft to use Windows Phone on its smartphones. Palm was bought by [[Hewlett-Packard]], turned into [[webOS]], and later demised. BlackBerry also made a new system from scratch, [[BlackBerry 10]].
The iPhone also had a knock-on effect on smartphone form factors. Before 2007 it was common for devices to have a numeric keypad or [[QWERTY]] keyboard in either a candybar or sliding form factor. However, by 2010, there were no top-tier smartphones with numeric keypads. {{As of|2014}}, [[BlackBerry Limited]] – with a 0.6% share of the market in Q4 2013 – is the sole remaining brand of high-end smartphones with physical keyboards.
===The future===
In 2013, the [[Fairphone]] company launched its first "socially ethical" smartphone at the [[London Design Festival]] to address concerns regarding the sourcing of materials in the manufacturing.{{cite news|title=Why is Apple so shifty about how it makes the iPhone?|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/sep/23/apple-shifty-about-making-iphone?CMP=EMCNEWEML6619I2&et_cid=50104&et_rid=7107573&Linkid=http%3a%2f%2fwww.theguardian.com%2fcommentisfree%2f2013%2fsep%2f23%2fapple-shifty-about-making-iphone|accessdate=24 September 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=23 September 2013|author=George Monbiot}} In late 2013, QSAlpha commenced production of a smartphone designed entirely around security, encryption and identity protection.{{cite web|title=Quasar IV Encrypted Ninja Smartphone Goes Into Production, Despite Indiegogo Failure|url=http://techcrunch.com/2013/10/09/quasar-iv-encrypted-ninja-smartphone-goes-into-production-despite-indiegogo-failure/?ncid=tcdaily|work=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL Inc|accessdate=10 October 2013|author=Darrell Etherington|date=10 October 2013}} In December 2013, the world's first curved-[[OLED]] technology smartphones were introduced to the retail market with the sale of the Samsung Galaxy Round and LG G Flex models.{{cite news|title=Bendable smartphones aren't coming anytime soon|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/mobiles/bendable-smartphones-arent-coming-anytime-soon-20131213-2zbtq.html|accessdate=26 December 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=16 December 2013|author=Ian King}}
Foldable [[OLED]] smartphones could be as much as a decade away because of the cost of producing them. There is a relatively high failure rate when producing these screens. As little as a speck of dust can ruin a screen during production. Creating a battery that can be folded is another hurdle.[http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/mobiles/bendable-smartphones-arent-coming-anytime-soon-20131213-2zbtq.html Bendable smartphones aren't coming anytime soon], The Sydney Morning Herald, Ian King, 16 December 2013 Samsung fully foldable phones are expected around 2016 to 2017.[http://news.yahoo.com/samsung-phone-bended-display-may-160221151.html Samsung Phone With Bended Display May Come This Year], LAPTOP, 11 February 2014, Lisa Eadicicco
A clear thin layer of crystal glass can be added to small screens like watches and smartphones that make them solar powered. Smartphones could gain 15% more battery life during a typical day. The first smartphones using this technology should arrive in 2015. This screen can also work to receive [[Li-Fi]] signals and so can the smartphone camera.[http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/the-internet-of-light-the-first-li-fi-smartphone-debuts-at-ces An Internet of Light: Going Online with LEDs and the First Li-Fi Smartphone], Motherboard Beta, Brian Merchant The cost of these screens per smartphone is between $2 and $3, much cheaper than most new technology.[http://www.digitaltrends.com/mobile/wysips-solar-charging-screen-li-fi-impressions/ Your next phone may charge and receive data through this incredible screen], Digital Trends, 19 January 2014, Jeffrey Van Camp
Near future smartphones might not have a traditional battery as their sole source of power. Instead, they may pull energy from radio, television, cellular or Wi-Fi signals.[http://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/03/technology/building-a-better-battery.html?partner=yahoofinance&_r=1 Building a Better Battery], NY Times, 2 February 2014, BRIAN X. CHEN and NICK BILTON
In early 2014, smartphones are beginning to use [[Quad HD]] (2K) 2560x1440 on 5.5" screens with up to 534 [[Pixel density|ppi]] on devices such as the [[LG G3]] which is a significant improvement over Apple's [[retina display]]. Quad HD is used in advanced televisions and computer monitors, but with 110 ppi or less on such larger displays.{{cite web |url=http://www.engadget.com/2014/02/18/do-you-really-need-a-4k-smartphone-screen/ |title=Do you really need a 4K smartphone screen? |author=Steve Dent |date=February 18, 2014}}
In 2014, Wi-Fi will continue to become the primary network for smartphones. As these devices do more and more with data and Wi-Fi becomes more prevalent and easier to connect to, Wi-Fi First smartphones service will start to take off.[http://www.wired.com/insights/2014/01/collision-course-wi-fi-first-role-changing-mobile-communications/], Wired, 8 January 2014, Alan Berrey[http://www.lightreading.com/mobile/carrier-wifi/why-wifi-first-works-for-wireless/d/d-id/707117], LightReading, 30 December 2013, Sarah Reddy[http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2425853,00.asp], PC Mag, 16 October 2013, Stephanie Mlot
Since 2013, water and dustproofing have made their way into mainstream high end smartphones instead of specialist models with the [[Sony Xperia Z]] continuing through the [[Sony Xperia Z2]] and also from other manufacturers with the [[Samsung Galaxy S5]].{{cite web |url=http://en.tempo.co/read/news/2014/03/01/240558504/Sony-Xperia-Z2-Ready-to-Compete-With-Samsung-Galaxy-S5 |title=Sony Xperia Z2 Ready to Compete With Samsung Galaxy S5 |author=Rindu P Hestya |date=March 1, 2014}}
==Mobile operating systems== {{Main|Mobile operating system}}
===Android=== {{Main|Android (operating system)}} [[File:Android 4.4.2.png|thumb|100px|Android 4.4.2 home screen]] [[Android (operating system)|''Android'']] is an [[open source|open-source]] platform founded in October 2003 by Andy Rubin and backed by [[Google]], along with major hardware and software developers (such as [[Intel]], [[HTC Corporation|HTC]], [[ARM Holdings|ARM]], [[Motorola]] and [[Samsung]]) that form the [[Open Handset Alliance]]. In October 2008, [[HTC]] released the [[HTC Dream]], the first phone to use Android.{{cite press release|url=http://www.opt-development.co.uk/press-office/release.php?id=242 |title=T-Mobile G1 Hits the UK|publisher=[[T-Mobile]] UK |date=30 October 2008}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.talkandroid.com/260-t-mobile-g1-details |title=T-Mobile G1 Event Round-up|publisher=[[Talk Media Inc.]] US |date=22 October 2008}} The software suite included on the phone consists of integration with Google's proprietary applications, such as [[Google Maps|Maps]], [[Google Calendar|Calendar]], and [[Gmail]], and a full HTML web browser. Android supports the execution of native applications and third-party apps which are available via [[Google Play]], which launched in October 2008 as [[Android Market]]. By Q4 2010, Android became the best-selling smartphone platform.{{cite news|url=http://gigaom.com/2010/08/02/android-sales-overtake-iphone-in-the-u-s/ |title=Android sales overtake iPhone in the US|publisher=Gigaom| date=2 August 2010}} {{-}} ===iOS=== {{Main|iOS}} [[File:IPhone 2G PSD Mock.png|thumb|upright|100px|The original [[iPhone]] (2007)]] In 2007, [[Apple Inc.]] introduced the [[iPhone (original)|iPhone]], one of the first mobile phones to use a [[multi-touch]] interface. The iPhone was notable for its use of a large touchscreen for direct finger input as its main means of interaction, instead of a [[Stylus (computing)|stylus]], keyboard, or keypad as typical for smartphones at the time. In July 2008, Apple introduced its second generation [[iPhone 3G|iPhone]] with a much lower list price and 3G support. Simultaneously, they introduced the [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]], which allowed any iPhone to install third-party native applications. Featuring over 500 applications at launch,{{cite web |url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2008/07/10iphone.html |title=iPhone 3G on Sale Tomorrow |date=2008-07-10 |publisher=Apple Inc. |work=Press Release |accessdate=2009-01-17}} the App Store eventually achieved 1 billion downloads in the first year, and 15 billion by 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2009/07/14Apples-App-Store-Downloads-Top-1-5-Billion-in-First-Year.html |title=Apple’s App Store Downloads Top 1.5 Billion in First Year |date=July 14, 2009 |publisher=Apple Inc. |work=Press Release |accessdate=2011-12-15}}{{cite web |url=http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2011/07/07Apples-App-Store-Downloads-Top-15-Billion.html |title=Apple's App Store Downloads Top 15 Billion |work=Press Release |date=July 7, 2011 |publisher=Apple Inc. |accessdate=2011-12-15}} {{-}} ===Windows Phone=== {{main|Windows Phone}}
In February 2010, Microsoft unveiled [[Windows Phone 7]] with a [[User Interface]] inspired by Microsoft's "[[Metro Design Language]]", to replace Windows Mobile. Windows Phone 7 integrates with Microsoft services such as [[SkyDrive|Microsoft SkyDrive]], [[Microsoft Office Mobile|Office]], [[Xbox]] and [[Microsoft Bing|Bing]], as well as non-Microsoft services such as [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]] and [[Google Account|Google accounts]]. This software platform runs the [[Microsoft Mobile]] smartphones, and has received some positive reception from the technology press and been praised for its uniqueness and differentiation.{{cite web |url= http://www.engadget.com/2010/02/15/windows-phone-7-series-is-official-and-microsoft-is-playing-to/ |title=Windows Phone 7 Series is official, and Microsoft is playing to win |publisher=Engadget |date=2010-02-15 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}{{cite web|author=Matt Buchanan |url=http://gizmodo.com/5471805/windows-phone-7-series-everything-is-different-now |title=Windows Phone 7 Series: Everything Is Different Now |publisher=Gizmodo.com |date=2010-02-15 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}{{cite web|author=Devin Coldewey |url=http://www.crunchgear.com/2010/02/15/windows-phone-7-series-our-take/ |title=Windows Phone 7 Series: Our Take | TechCrunch |publisher=Crunchgear.com |date=2010-02-15 |accessdate=2011-09-07}}
===Firefox OS=== {{main|Firefox OS}}
Firefox OS (originally called the ''boot to gecko'' project) was demonstrated by [[Mozilla]] in February 2012. It was designed to have a complete community based alternative system for mobile devices, using open standards and HTML5 applications. The first commercially available Firefox OS phones were ZTE Open and Alcatel One Touch Fire. As of 2014 more companies have partnered with Mozilla including Panasonic (which is making a smart TV with Firefox OS) and Sony.{{cite web|author=Feb 26 2013 |url=http://www.mozillaphilippines.org/sony-mobile-plans-to-release-firefox-os-devices-by-2014/ |title=Sony Mobile Plans to Release Firefox OS Devices by 2014 |publisher=Mozilla Philippines |date=2013-02-25 |accessdate=2014-06-17}}
===Tizen=== {{main|Tizen}} '''Tizen''' is a [[Linux kernel|Linux]]-based [[operating system]] for devices, including smartphones, [[tablet computer|tablets]], [[In car entertainment|in-vehicle infotainment]] (IVI) devices, [[smart TV]]s, [[laptop]]s and smart cameras. Tizen is a project within the [[Linux Foundation]] and is governed by a Technical Steering Group (TSG) composed of [[Samsung]] and [[Intel]] among others.
In April 2014, Samsung released the Samsung Gear 2 and the Gear 2 Neo, running Tizen.{{cite web | title=Samsung's wrist reboot: Gear 2 and Gear 2 Neo unveiled | author=Techradar | url=http://www.techradar.com/au/news/portable-devices/samsung-s-tizen-smartwatch-to-drop-galaxy-branding-galaxy-gear-2-also-leaked-1227419 | publisher=Techradar | date=2014-02-23 | accessdate=2014-02-23}}
===Sailfish OS=== {{main|Sailfish OS}}
The Sailfish OS is based on the [[Linux kernel]] and [[Mer (software distribution)|Mer]].{{cite web|first=Sailfish OS community|title=The Sailfish OS Wiki|url=https://sailfishos.org/wiki/Main_Page#Contribute|work=The Sailfish OS Wiki|accessdate=14 March 2013}} Additionally Sailfish OS includes a partially or completely [[proprietary software|proprietary]] multi-tasking [[user interface]] programmed by [[Jolla]]. This user interface differentiate Jolla smartphones from others.{{cite web | title = Jolla OS Will Run Android Apps Says CEO Jussi Hurmola | url = http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/375368/20120820/jolla-os-running-android-apps-jussi-hurmola.htm}} Sailfish OS is intended to be a system made by many of the MeeGo team, which left [[Nokia]] to form Jolla, utilizing funding from Nokia's "Bridge" program which helps establish and support start-up companies formed by ex-Nokia employees.{{citation | url = http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Many+former+Nokia+employees+start+businesses+of+their+own/1329104331230 | title = Many former Nokia employees start businesses of their own | newspaper = Helsingin Sanomat}}{{cite web|last=Lunden|first=Ingrid|title=Nokia Bridge: Nokia’s Incubator Gives Departing Employees €25k And More To Pursue Ideas That Nokia Has Not|url=http://techcrunch.com/2012/07/10/nokia-bridge-nokias-incubator-gives-departing-employees-e25k-and-more-to-pursue-ideas-that-nokia-has-not/|work=techcrunch.com|publisher=techcrunch.com|accessdate=7 June 2013}}{{cite web|last=Tung|first=Liam|title=Inside Nokia Bridge: How Nokia funds ex-employees' new start-ups|url=http://www.zdnet.com/inside-nokia-bridge-how-nokia-funds-ex-employees-new-start-ups-7000000863/|work=zdnet.com|publisher=© 2013 CBS Interactive|accessdate=7 June 2013}}
===BlackBerry=== {{main|BlackBerry}} [[File:Blackberry 8900 ColorIsOff.jpg|thumb|100px|[[BlackBerry Curve]] 8900 (2008)]] In 1999, [[Research In Motion|RIM]] released its first [[BlackBerry]] devices, providing secure real-time push-email communications on wireless devices. Services such as BlackBerry Messenger provide the integration of all communications into a single inbox. There are 80 million active BlackBerry service subscribers and the 200 millionth BlackBerry smartphone was shipped in September 2012.[http://www.rim.com/investors/documents/pdf/financial/2011/Q1_financial_information.pdf 100 millionth BlackBerry smartphone shipped in June 2010] Most recently, RIM has undergone a platform transition, changing its name to BlackBerry and making new devices on a new platform named "BlackBerry 10."{{cite web |author=Kevin McLaughlin |url=http://www.crn.com/news/client-devices/222002587/blackberry-users-call-for-rim-to-rethink-service.htm |title=BlackBerry Users Call For RIM To Rethink Service |publisher=CRN.com |date=December 17, 2009 |accessdate=2011-12-15}} {{-}} ===Symbian=== {{Main|Symbian}} [[File:Nokia N8 (front view).jpg|thumb|100px|[[Nokia N8]] (2010)]] Symbian was originally developed by [[Psion]] as [[EPOC32]]. It was the world's most widely used smartphone operating system until Q4 2010, though the platform never gained popularity or widespread awareness in the U.S., as it did in Europe and Asia. The first Symbian phone, the touchscreen [[Ericsson R380|Ericsson R380 Smartphone]], was released in 2000,{{cite web |url=http://www.geek.com/hwswrev/pda/ericr380/ |title=PDA Review: Ericsson R380 Smartphone |publisher=''Geek.com'' |accessdate=2011-12-15}}{{cite web |url=http://www.i-symbian.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/Symbian_Evolution.pdf |format=PDF |title= Symbian Device – The OS Evolution |publisher=''Independent Symbian Blog'' |accessdate=2011-12-15}} and was the first device marketed as a "smartphone".{{cite web |url=http://www.mobilemag.com/2001/09/25/ericsson-introduces-the-new-r380e |title=Ericsson Introduces The New R380e |publisher=''Mobile Magazine'' |accessdate=2011-12-15}} It combined a PDA with a mobile phone.{{cite news |url=http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,40827,00.asp |title=Ericsson R380 World, Review & Rating |publisher=''PCMag.com'' |accessdate=2011-12-15 |first=Bruce |last=Brown}} In February 2011, Nokia announced that it would replace Symbian with [[Windows Phone]] as the operating system on all of its future smartphones, with the platform getting abandoned throughout the following few years.{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2011/02/11/nokia-microsoft-smart-phone-apple-google.html |title=Nokia, Microsoft in pact to rival Apple, Google – Technology & Science |publisher=CBC.ca |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-12-15}} {{-}} ===Windows Mobile=== {{main|Windows Mobile}} [[File:HTC kaiser smartphone2.jpg|file|thumb|100px|[[HTC Kaiser]] (2009)]] Windows Mobile was based on the [[Windows CE]] kernel and first appeared as the Pocket PC 2000 operating system. Throughout its lifespan, the operating system was available in both touchscreen and non-touchscreen formats. It was supplied with a suite of applications developed with the Microsoft Windows API and was designed to have features and appearance somewhat similar to desktop versions of Windows. Third parties could develop software for Windows Mobile with no restrictions imposed by Microsoft. Software applications were eventually purchasable from Windows Marketplace for Mobile during the service's brief lifespan. Windows mobile was phased out in favor of Windows Phone. {{-}} ===Palm OS=== [[File:Treo650-Sprint.png|100px|thumb|[[Palm Treo]] 650 (2004)]] {{main|Palm OS}} In late 2001, Handspring launched their own Springboard GSM phone module with limIn. Early 2002, [[Handspring (company)|Handspring]] released the [[Palm OS]] [[Palm Treo|Treo]] smartphone with both a touch screen and a full keyboard. The Treo had wireless web browsing, email, calendar, a contact organizer and mobile third-party applications that could be downloaded or synced with a computer.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/nov2001/nf20011129_0157.htm |author=Stephen H. Wildstrom |title=Handspring's Breakthrough Hybrid |publisher=Businessweek.com |date=November 30, 2001 |accessdate=2011-12-15}} Handspring was soon acquired by Palm, which released the Treo 600 and continued, though the series eventually took on Windows Mobile. After buying [[Palm, Inc]], in 2011 [[Hewlett-Packard]] (HP) finally discontinued its smartphones and tablets production using [[webOS]] which is initial developed by Palm, Inc.{{cite web |url=http://www.brighthand.com/default.asp?newsID=18078&news=HP+webOS+Palm+RIM |title=HP To Stop Making webOS Smartphones, Might License the OS to Others |accessdate=November 26, 2013}} {{-}} ===Bada=== {{main|Bada}} The Bada operating system for smartphones was announced by Samsung in November 2009.{{cite news |title=Samsung Bailing on Windows Mobile |newspaper=[[InformationWeek]] |author=Ed Hansberry |date=11 November 2009 |url=http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2009/11/samsung_bailing.html}}{{cite news |title=Samsung to Discard Windows Phone |newspaper=Telecoms Korea |date=9 November 2009 |url=http://www.telecomskorea.com/market-8281.html}} The first Bada-based phone was the [[Samsung S8500|Samsung Wave S8500]], released in June 2010.{{cite news |title=Samsung Wave, first Bada smartphone hits the market |url=http://www.bada.com/samsung-wave-first-bada-smartphone-hits-the-market/ |work=Bada |date=24 May 2010 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://badawave.com/ |title=BadaWave |publisher=BadaWave |accessdate=2012-01-05}}{{cite web |url=http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/1722287/samsung-waves-away-million |title=Samsung Waves away a million |date=13 July 2010 |publisher=[[The Inquirer]]}} Samsung shipped 4.5 million phones running Bada in Q2 of 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/PG.Biz/asymco+news/news.asp?c=32049 |title=Samsung Bada shipments up 355% to 4.5 million units in Q2 2011 | asymco news | PG.Biz |publisher=Pocket Gamer |accessdate=2011-09-07}} In 2013, Bada merged with a similar platform called [[Tizen]]. {{-}}
==Application stores== {{Main|List of digital distribution platforms for mobile devices}}
The introduction of Apple's [[App Store (iOS)|App Store]] for the iPhone and iPod Touch in July 2008 popularized manufacturer-hosted [[list of digital distribution platforms for mobile devices|online distribution]] for third-party applications ([[software]], [[computer programs]]) focused on a single platform. Up until that point, smartphone application distribution depended on [[List of digital distribution platforms for mobile devices#Third-party platforms|third-party sources]] providing applications for multiple platforms, such as [[GetJar]], [[Handango]], [[Handmark]], and [[PocketGear]].
Following the success of the App Store, other smartphone manufacturers launched application stores, such as [[Google]]'s [[Android Market]] in October 2008 and [[Research In Motion|RIM]]'s [[BlackBerry App World]] in April 2009.
==Market share==
===Smartphone usage===
In the third quarter of 2012, one billion smartphones were in use worldwide.{{cite web|title=Worldwide smartphone user base hits 1 billion|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1035_3-57534132-94/worldwide-smartphone-user-base-hits-1-billion/|work=CNet|publisher=CBS Interactive, Inc|accessdate=26 July 2013|author=Don Reisinger|date=17 October 2012}} Global smartphone sales surpassed the sales figures for features phones in early 2013.{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Smartphones-now-outsell-dumb-phones/tabid/412/articleID/295878/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Smartphones now outsell 'dumb' phones| date=April 29, 2013}} As of 2013, 65 percent U.S. mobile consumers own smartphones.{{cite web |url=http://www.engadget.com/2014/02/11/two-thirds-of-americans-now-have-smartphones/ |title=Two-thirds of Americans now have smartphones |author=Jon Fingas |date=February 11, 2014}} The European mobile device market as of 2013 is 860 million.{{cite web|title=European Mobile Market|url=http://www.telecomsmarketresearch.com/resources/Mobile_Market_Europe.shtml|work=telecoms market research|publisher=CMSinfo|accessdate=27 June 2013|year=2011}} In China, smartphones represented more than half of all handset shipments in the second quarter of 2012.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.ft.com/beyond-brics/2012/08/24/apple-in-china-not-as-cool-as-before/ |title=Apple in China: not as cool as before |author=beyondbrics |date=2012-08-24|accessdate= 2012-08-30|work= [[ft.com]]}}
As of November 2011, 27% of all photographs were taken with camera-equipped smartphones.{{cite web|title=Smartphones killing point-and-shoots, now take almost 1/3 of photos|url=http://gigaom.com/2011/12/22/smartphones-killing-point-and-shoots-now-take-almost-13-of-photos/|work=GIGAOM|publisher=GIGAOM|accessdate=27 June 2013|author=Erica Ogg|date=22 December 2011}} A study conducted in September 2012 concluded that 4 out of 5 smartphone owners use the device to shop.{{cite web|title=comScore: 4 Out Of 5 Smartphone Owners Use Device To Shop; Amazon Is The Most Popular Mobile Retailer|url=http://techcrunch.com/2012/09/19/comscore-4-out-of-5-smartphone-owners-use-device-to-shop-amazon-most-popular-mobile-retailer/|work=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL Inc|accessdate=27 June 2013|author=Leena Rao|date=19 September 2012}} Another study conducted in June 2013 concluded that 56% of American adults now owned a smartphone of some kind. Android and iPhone owners account for half of the cell phone user population. Higher income adults and those under age 35 lead the way when it comes to smartphone ownership.http://boletines.prisadigital.com/PIP_Smartphone_adoption_2013.pdf
Worldwide shipments of smartphones topped 1 billion units in 2013 (up 38% from 2012's 725 million) while comprising a 55% share of the mobile phone market in 2013 (up from 42% in 2012).{{cite web | title = Worldwide Smartphone Shipments Top One Billion Units for the First Time, According to IDC | author = | publisher = IDC | date = January 2014 | url = http://www.idc.com/getdoc.jsp?containerId=prUS24645514 | accessdate = 2014-01-27 }}
===By manufacturer=== [[File:Smartphones.jpg|thumb|[[Samsung]] smartphones with [[Android (operating system)|Android]] OS]] In 2013, Samsung had 31.3 percent shipment [[market share]], a slight increase from 30.3 percent in 2012, while Apple was at 15.3 percent, a decrease from 18.7 percent in 2012. [[Huawei]], [[LG]] and [[Lenovo]] were at about 5 percent each, significantly better than 2012 figures, while others had about 40 percent, the same as the previous years figure. Only Apple lost market share, although their shipment volume still increased by 12.9 percent; the rest had significant increases in shipment volumes of 36 to 92 percent.{{cite web |url=http://www.engadget.com/2014/01/28/smartphone-sales-may-have-topped-1-billion-in-2013/ |title=Smartphone sales may have topped 1 billion in 2013, depending on who you ask |work=[[Engadget]] |author=Jon Fingas |date=January 28, 2014}} In Q1 of 2014, [[Samsung]] had a 31% share and Apple had 16%.{{cite web |url= http://www.techinasia.com/xiaomi-global-top-10-smartphone-shipments-q1-2014/|title= Xiaomi breaks into global top 10 for smartphone shipments, kicks out HTC|author= Steven Millward|date= May 13, 2014|accessdate= September 9, 2014|work= Tech In Asia}}
===By operating system=== {{main|Mobile operating system}} The market has been dominated by the Android operating system since 2010. Android's market share (measured by units shipment) rose from 33.2% in Q4 2011 to 78.1% of the market in Q4 2013. Apple managed to oscillate their market share between 15% to 20.9% during the same period. BlackBerry's market share fell from 14.3% in Q4 2011 to 0.6% in Q4 2013. MS Windows Mobile market share rose from 1.5% to 3% during the same time frame.{{cite web |url=http://www.idc.com/prodserv/smartphone-os-market-share.jsp |title=IDC: Smartphone OS Market Share |accessdate=March 26, 2014}}
As of the end of Q2 2014, Android was the most popular operating system, with a 84.7% market share, followed by iOS with 11.7%, Windows Phone with 2.5% and BlackBerry with 0.5%.{{cite web |url=http://www.idc.com/prodserv/smartphone-os-market-share.jsp |title=Smartphone OS Market Share, Q2 2014 |accessdate=September 27, 2014}}

==Issues==
===Battery life=== [[File:USB battery charger.jpg|thumbnail|A high-capacity portable battery charger]] Compared to current generation non-smartphones, smartphone's battery life has generally been poor which has become a significant drain on customer satisfaction.{{cite web|title=J.D. Power and Associates Reports: Smartphone Battery Life has Become a Significant Drain on Customer Satisfaction and Loyalty|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/jd-power-and-associates-reports-smartphone-battery-life-has-become-a-significant-drain-on-customer-satisfaction-and-loyalty-142765065.html|accessdate=11 September 2014}}[http://www.zdnet.com/the-secret-behind-poor-smartphone-battery-life-7000032270/ ZDNet - The secret behind poor smartphone battery life][http://techland.time.com/2013/04/01/peak-battery-why-smartphone-battery-life-still-stinks-and-will-for-years/ Time - Peak Battery: Why Smartphone Battery Life Still Stinks, and Will for Years]
===Environmental===
Obtaining the resources required to create smartphones involves the mining of [[minerals]] such as [[coltan]], which are toxic to humans and wildlife.Ebersole, R 2003, 'Recycle Cell Phones, Reduce Toxic Trash', ''National Wildlife (World Edition)'', 41, 4, p. 14, Science Reference Center, EBSCOhost, retrieved 14 August 2013. Other raw materials, such as oils, copper, plastics, and solvents, have the potential to contaminate both the soil and groundwater. Smartphones also contain toxic chemicals such as lead, [[bromine]], [[chlorine]], [[Mercury (element)|mercury]], and [[cadmium]].'Mobile phones a pollution risk'2007, New Scientist, 194, 2600, p. 23, Science Reference Center, EBSCOhost, retrieved 14 August 2013.
The improper recycling of used smartphones damages the environment."Cellphones: a pollution risk environment" 2007, Science news and science jobs from New Scientist. http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19426006.500-cellphones-a-pollution-risk.html. Retrieved on 14 August 2013. Mobile phones can contain dangerous chemicals such as [[antimony]], cadmium, [[copper]], lead, [[arsenic]], [[nickel]] and [[zinc]], which can run off into surrounding water bodies or seep into soil contaminating wildlife and drinking water.Wall, Tim. (October 5, 2012) "Cellphones toxic to humans and Earth". http://news.discovery.com/earth/cell-phones-toxic-121005.html. Retrieved 14 August 2013.
===Worker conditions===
The [[capacitors]] in electronics use minerals mined in [[developing countries]]. Mines in [[Rwanda]], for example, have been associated with [[human rights]] and [[labor rights]] violations.“Coltan: a new blood mineral”. (2010, December 10). CBC.ca– Technology and Science. [http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2010/12/10/coltan-faq.html http://www.cbc.ca/new] s [http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2010/12/10/coltan-faq.html /technology/story/2010/12/10/coltan-faq.html]. Retrieved 14 August 2013. Workers, including children, have been forced to work at gunpoint while mining for smartphone materials.
The electronics soldering in smartphones require tin, 30% of which comes from the Indonesian islands of [[Bangka Island|Bangka]] and [[Belitung]]. The tin extraction process has been identified as environmentally destructive and, as of September 2013, children are employed in hazardous conditions to extract tin.{{cite web|title=Mobile industry tackles tin problems after Friends of the Earth campaign|url=http://foe.co.uk/resource/press_releases/mobile_industry_bangka_31072013.html|work=Friends of the Earth|publisher=Friends of the Earth Trust/Limited|accessdate=24 September 2013|format=Press release|date=31 July 2013}}
===Social=== {{Main|Smartphone addiction}} A University of Southern California study found that the [[Safe sex|unprotected]] [[adolescent sexuality|adolescent sexual]] activity was more common amongst owners of smartphones.[http://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/11/01/smartphones_more_sexually_active/ "SMARTPHONES make TEENS have SEX with STRANGERS."] A study conducted by the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]]'s (RPI) Lighting Research Center (LRC) concluded that smartphones, or any backlit devices, can seriously affect sleep cycles.{{cite news|last=Colaner|first=Seth|title=our Tablet and Smartphone Could Be Ruining Your Sleep|url=http://hothardware.com/News/Your-Tablet-and-Smartphone-are-Ruining-Your-Sleep-/|accessdate=22 January 2014|date=27 August 2012}}
===Legal=== {{Main|Smartphone wars}} A "patent war" between Samsung and Apple started when the latter claimed that the original [[Samsung Galaxy S|Galaxy S]] Android phone copied the interface—and possibly the hardware—of Apple's iOS for the [[iPhone 3GS]].
{{Main|Mobile medical apps}} With the raise in number of [[mobile medical apps]] in the market place, government regulatory agencies raised concerns on the safety of the use of such applications. These concerns were transformed into regulation initiatives world wide with the aim of safeguarding users from untrusted medical advice.Yetisen, A. K., Martinez-Hurtado, J. L., et al (2014). The regulation of mobile medical applications. Lab on a Chip, 14(5), 833-840. dx.doi.org/10.1039/C3LC51235E
===Security===
{{Main|Mobile security|Malware|Mobile virus|Media Transfer Protocol}}
Smartphone malware is more easily distributed through application stores that have minimal or no security mechanisms.[http://globalthreatcenter.com/?p=2492 Mobile Malware Development Continues To Rise, Android Leads The Way].{{cite book|title=8th International Conference on Trust, Privacy & Security in Digital Business (TRUSTBUS-2011)|year=2011|publisher=Springer Berlin / Heidelberg|pages=49–61|author=Mylonas Alexios|authorlink=A Secure Smartphone Applications Roll-out Scheme|author2=Tsoumas Bill |author3=Dritsas Stelios |author4=Gritzalis Dimitris }} Often malware is hidden in [[Copyright infringement of software|pirated]] versions of legitimate apps, which are then distributed through 3rd party app stores.{{cite news |url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2011/03/01/the-mother-of-all-android-malware-has-arrived-stolen-apps-released-to-the-market-that-root-your-phone-steal-your-data-and-open-backdoor/ |title = The Mother Of All Android Malware Has Arrived |work=Android Police |first=Android Police |date=March 6, 2011 }}{{cite web |last=Perez |first=Sarah |url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/android_vulnerability_so_dangerous_shouldnt_use_web_browser.php |title=Android Vulnerability So Dangerous, Owners Warned Not to Use Phone's Web Browser |publisher=Readwriteweb.com |date=2009-02-12 |accessdate=2011-08-08}} Malware risk also comes from what's known as an "update attack", where a legitimate application is later changed to include a malware component, which users then install when they are notified that the app has been updated.{{cite web|url=http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/11/08/03/lookout_retrevio_warn_of_growing_android_malware_epidemic_note_apples_ios_is_far_safer.html |title=Lookout, Retrevo warn of growing Android malware epidemic, note Apple's iOS is far safer |publisher=Appleinsider.com |date=2011-08-03 |accessdate=2012-01-05}}
One out of three robberies involve the theft of a mobile phone. An online petition urging that smartphone makers to install [[kill switch]]es in their devices is underway.[http://www.sfexaminer.com/sanfrancisco/plea-urges-anti-theft-phone-tech/Content?oid=2447711 Aldax, Mike "Plea Urges Anti-Theft Phone Tech" ''San Francisco Examiner'' Friday, June 7, 2013 Page 5:]
In order to minimize the chances of being a victim of theft of mobile devices, there have been several apps created to help those out that may be in a dangerous situation. There are now apps that may aid in personal security by providing immediate assistance.
===Disturbing sleep=== Using smartphones late at night can disturb sleep due to the bright screen light affecting melatonin levels and sleep cycles.{{cite web|author=Luisa Dillner |url=http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2013/jun/09/smartphones-tablets-in-bedroom-sleep |title=Should I keep my smartphone and tablet out of my bedroom? | Life and style |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=2014-06-17}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/06/130603163610.htm |title=Are smartphones disrupting your sleep? |publisher=ScienceDaily |accessdate=2014-06-17}}{{cite web|author=Mahesh Sharma |url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/digital-life-news/switching-off-your-smartphone-at-night-makes-you-more-productive-20140403-zqpc4.html |title=Switching off your smartphone at night makes you more productive |publisher=Smh.com.au |accessdate=2014-06-17}}One of the best biological cues we have to [tell] what time of day it is, is light. And it turns out that blue light in particular is very effective at basically predicting when morning is,” Brian Zoltowski from the American Chemical Society [http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/smart-phones-can-ruin-your-sleep/article6031259.ece]
